content.description: TABLE 1. POLLINATOR VISITATION RATES TO TWO SPECIES OF MIMULUS
content.question: Mimulus Species and Flower Color Bumblebees(<math alttext="10 to the negative three power visits per flower per hour" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mtext>10</mtext><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mi>visits</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>flower</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>hour</mi></math>) Hummingbirds(<math alttext="10 to the negative three power visits per flower per hour" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mtext>10</mtext><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mi>visits</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>flower</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>hour</mi></math>) M. lewisii (wild-type, pink) <math alttext="15.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>15.4</mn></math> <math alttext="0.021" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.021</mn></math> M. lewisii (mutant, orange) <math alttext="2.63" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.63</mn></math> <math alttext="1.44" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.44</mn></math> M. cardinalis (wild-type, red) <math alttext="0.148" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.148</mn></math> <math alttext="189" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>189</mn></math> M. cardinalis (mutant, pink) <math alttext="10.9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10.9</mn></math> <math alttext="168" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>168</mn></math> Plant species in the genus Mimulus have evolved specialized flower structures and colors that attract pollinators. Researchers identified mutant forms of two of the species, Mimulus lewisii and Mimulus cardinalis, that have different flower colors from the wild-type forms. They measured the number of visits by two pollinators, bumblebees and hummingbirds, to the flowers of the wild-type and mutant species (Table 1). Which of the following statements best describes the data shown in Table 1 ?

choices.label: Bumblebees visited wild-type M. lewisii approximately <math alttext="13" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>13</mn></math> times more frequently than they did mutant M. lewisii.
Hummingbirds preferred wild-type M. lewisii over wild-type M. cardinalis.
Hummingbirds preferred the pink flower type in both M. lewisii and M. cardinalis.
Bumblebees visited mutant M. cardinalis approximately <math alttext="70" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>70</mn></math> times more frequently than they did wild-type M. cardinalis.

content.answer: Bumblebees visited mutant M. cardinalis approximately <math alttext="70" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>70</mn></math> times more frequently than they did wild-type M. cardinalis.

skill.text: 4.B: Describe data from a table or graph, including: i. identifying specific data points ii. describing trends and patterns in the data iii. describing relationships between variables
